abstract: Media Equation: How headlines have changed in the age of Google and other search engines.
snippet: Media Equation: How headlines have changed in the age of Google and other search engines.
lead_paragraph: In his Media Equation column on Monday, David Carr mentions Taylor Momsen, whom he doesn’t know, except that she is a mean character on “Gossip Girl” and one of the most frequently used search terms on the Web. His real subject is the way that Google and other search engines are changing the way media companies think about headlines. Once upon a time, headlines were used to attract readers by conveying simple, clear information about what was in the story. Now, on the Web, they are used to attract the attention of search engines and social networking sites, using buzz words (“Taylor Momsen!”) and double entendres. He writes:

headline.main: Media Equation: Taylor Momsen, Google Bait
